Source code structures¶

Class: Representations¶

class PyMieSim.Representations.Footprint() -> new empty dictionary dict(mapping) -> new dictionary initialized from a mapping object's (key, value) pairs dict(iterable) -> new dictionary initialized as if via: d = {} for k, v in iterable: d[k] = v dict(**kwargs) -> new dictionary initialized with the name=value pairs in the keyword argument list. For example: dict(one=1, two=2)[source]¶

Bases: dict

clear() → None. Remove all items from D.¶
copy() → a shallow copy of D¶
fromkeys(iterable, value=None, /)¶

Create a new dictionary with keys from iterable and values set to value.

get(key, default=None, /)¶

Return the value for key if key is in the dictionary, else default.

items() → a set-like object providing a view on D's items¶
keys() → a set-like object providing a view on D's keys¶
pop(k[, d]) → v, remove specified key and return the corresponding value.¶

If key is not found, d is returned if given, otherwise KeyError is raised

popitem(/)¶

Remove and return a (key, value) pair as a 2-tuple.

Pairs are returned in LIFO (last-in, first-out) order. Raises KeyError if the dict is empty.

setdefault(key, default=None, /)¶

Insert key with a value of default if key is not in the dictionary.

Return the value for key if key is in the dictionary, else default.

update([E, ]**F) → None. Update D from dict/iterable E and F.¶

If E is present and has a .keys() method, then does: for k in E: D[k] = E[k] If E is present and lacks a .keys() method, then does: for k, v in E: D[k] = v In either case, this is followed by: for k in F: D[k] = F[k]

values() → an object providing a view on D's values¶
class PyMieSim.Representations.S1S2() -> new empty dictionary dict(mapping) -> new dictionary initialized from a mapping object's (key, value) pairs dict(iterable) -> new dictionary initialized as if via: d = {} for k, v in iterable: d[k] = v dict(**kwargs) -> new dictionary initialized with the name=value pairs in the keyword argument list. For example: dict(one=1, two=2)[source]¶

copy() → a shallow copy of D¶
fromkeys(iterable, value=None, /)¶

Create a new dictionary with keys from iterable and values set to value.

get(key, default=None, /)¶

Return the value for key if key is in the dictionary, else default.

items() → a set-like object providing a view on D's items¶
keys() → a set-like object providing a view on D's keys¶
pop(k[, d]) → v, remove specified key and return the corresponding value.¶

If key is not found, d is returned if given, otherwise KeyError is raised

popitem(/)¶

Remove and return a (key, value) pair as a 2-tuple.

Pairs are returned in LIFO (last-in, first-out) order. Raises KeyError if the dict is empty.

setdefault(key, default=None, /)¶

Insert key with a value of default if key is not in the dictionary.

Return the value for key if key is in the dictionary, else default.

update([E, ]**F) → None. Update D from dict/iterable E and F.¶

If E is present and has a .keys() method, then does: for k in E: D[k] = E[k] If E is present and lacks a .keys() method, then does: for k, v in E: D[k] = v In either case, this is followed by: for k in F: D[k] = F[k]

values() → an object providing a view on D's values¶

Plot(hold=False)[source]¶

Method plots the scattered Far-Field \(E_{\phi}(\phi,\theta)^2 , E_{\theta}(\phi,\theta)^2\).

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point to spatially (\(\theta , \phi\)) evaluate the SPF [Num, Num].

Source¶

PlaneWave¶

class PyMieSim.Source.PlaneWave(Wavelength: float, Polarization: float = 0, E0: float = 1)[source]¶

Bases: PyMieSim.BaseClasses.BaseSource

Class representing a focuse plane wave beam as a light source for light scattering.

Parameters:
  • Wavelength (float) – Wavelenght of the light field.
  • Polarization (float) – Polarization of the light field.
  • E0 (float) – Maximal value of the electric field at focus point.
BSC(n, m, mode='TE')[source]¶

Return the beam shape coefficients (\(g^{l}_{n, TE}\), \(g^{l}_{n, TM}\)) for a plane wave. (Eq: VI.77 of G&G)

Parameters:
  • n (int) – Order of the expansion.
  • m (int) – Description of parameter m.
  • mode (str) – Mode of the plane wave, either ‘TE’ or ‘TM’.
Returns:

Expansion coefficient.
Return type:

float
EField(x, y, z)[source]¶

Value of the electric field.

\(E = E_0 \exp{ig( i k (z-z_0) ig) (p_x \vec{e_x}, p_y \vec{e_y})}\)

HField(x, y, z)[source]¶

Value of the electric field.

\(H = H_0 \exp{ig( i k (z-z_0) ig) (p_x \vec{e_x}, p_y \vec{e_y})}\)

I¶

Compute averaged value of Poyinting vector. \(I = <S> = \frac{c \epsilon_0}{2} E_0^2\)

GaussianBeam¶

class PyMieSim.Source.GaussianBeam(Wavelength: float, NA: float, Polarization: float = 0.0, E0: float = 1.0, Offset: list = [1e-20, 1e-20, 1e-20])[source]¶

Bases: PyMieSim.BaseClasses.BaseSource

Class representing a focuse Gaussian beam as a light source for light scattering.

Parameters:
  • Wavelength (float) – Wavelenght of the light field.
  • NA (float) – Numerical aperture of the beam.
  • Polarization (float) – Polarization of the light field.
  • E0 (float) – Maximal value of the electric field at focus point.
  • offset (list) – Distance offset of the beam in comparison to the scatterer.
Anm(n, m, Sampling=200)[source]¶

From ref[2]:Eq:18-19 Method returns:

\(A_{mn} = \gamma_0 \int_0^{\pi} \gamma_1 \big[ \hat{I}_{m+1} (\beta) + \hat{I}_{m-1} (\beta) \big] -\gamma_3 \hat{I}_{m} (\beta) d \theta\)

Where:

\(\gamma_0 = \frac{(-i)^n \rho_n^2}{(2n+1) \psi_n(\rho_n)}e^{-i Z_0}\)

\(\gamma_1 = Q \exp \big[ i Q s^2 \Big( R_0 - \rho_n \sin (\theta ) \big)^2 + i \rho_n \cos( \theta ) \Big] \hat{P}_n^{|m|} (\cos ( \theta ) ) \sin(\theta)\)

\(\gamma_2 = \big( 2 Q s^2 \rho_n \cos(\theta) -1 \big) \sin(\theta)\)

\(\gamma_3 = 4 Q s^2 X_0 \cos(\theta)\)

\(\gamma_4 = 4 Q s^2 Y_0 \cos(\theta)\)

\(I_m(\beta) = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} e^{z \cos(\phi) - i m \phi} d\phi\)

\(\tilde{I}_m(\beta) = e^{-\beta - i m \xi} I_m(\beta)\)

\(Q_{spherical} = \frac{1}{2 ( r \cos (\theta) - z_0 )/k w_0^2 - i}\)

Anm_integrand(n, m, Sampling=200)[source]¶

Method returns:

\(A_{mn} = \gamma_0 \int_0^{\pi} \gamma_1 \big[ \hat{I}_{m+1} (\beta) + \hat{I}_{m-1} (\beta) \big] -\gamma_3 \hat{I}_{m} (\beta) d \theta\)

BSC(n, m, mode='TE')[source]¶

Return the beam shape coefficients for a focused Gaussian beam using the quadrature method (ref[2]:Eq:17).

(\(g^{l}_{n, TE}\), \(g^{l}_{n, TM}\))

Parameters:
  • n (int) – Order of the expansion.
  • m (int) – Description of parameter m.
  • mode (str) – Mode of the plane wave, either ‘TE’ or ‘TM’.
Returns:

Beam shape coefficient of order n and degree m.
Return type:

float
Bnm(n, m)[source]¶

From ref[2]:Eq:18-19 Method returns:

\(B_{mn} = \gamma_0 \int_0^{\pi} \gamma_1 \big[ \hat{I}_{m+1} (\beta) - \hat{I}_{m-1} (\beta) \big] -\gamma_4 \hat{I}_{m} (\beta) d \theta\)

Where:

\(\gamma_0 = \frac{(-i)^n \rho_n^2}{(2n+1) \psi_n(\rho_n)}e^{-i Z_0}\)

\(\gamma_1 = Q \exp \big[ i Q s^2 \Big( R_0 - \rho_n \sin (\theta ) \big)^2 + i \rho_n \cos( \theta ) \Big] \hat{P}_n^{|m|} (\cos ( \theta ) ) \sin(\theta)\)

\(\gamma_2 = \big( 2 Q s^2 \rho_n \cos(\theta) -1 \big) \sin(\theta)\)

\(\gamma_3 = 4 Q s^2 X_0 \cos(\theta)\)

\(\gamma_4 = 4 Q s^2 Y_0 \cos(\theta)\)

\(I_m(\beta) = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} e^{z \cos(\phi) - i m \phi} d\phi\)

\(\tilde{I}_m(\beta) = e^{-\beta - i m \xi} I_m(\beta)\)

\(Q_{spherical} = \frac{1}{2 ( r \cos (\theta) - z_0 )/k w_0^2 - i}\)

Bnm_integrand(n, m, Sampling=200)[source]¶

Method returns:

\(A_{mn} = \gamma_0 \int_0^{\pi} \gamma_1 \big[ \hat{I}_{m+1} (\beta) + \hat{I}_{m-1} (\beta) \big] -\gamma_3 \hat{I}_{m} (\beta) d \theta\)

EField(x, y, z)[source]¶

Value of the electric Field (First Order) ref[2]:Eq:6 \(E = E_0 \exp{ig( i k (z-z_0) ig) (p_x \vec{e_x}, p_y \vec{e_y})}\).

Er(r, phi, theta)[source]¶

Value of the electric Field (First Order) ref[2]:Eq:10 \(E_r = E_0 \Phi_0 \Big[ \sin (\theta) \cos (\phi) - \frac{2Q}{kw_0^2} \cos (\theta) \big( r \sin (\theta) \cos (\phi) -x_0 \big) \Big] \exp^{ik (r \cos (\theta) -z_0 )}\).

GetMaxOrder(Precision=5)[source]¶

Method return the range of order to evaluate the BSC’s. However one should be cautious as a high precision will lead to numerical overflow.

Parameters:Precision (int) – Precision parameter (standard is 20)
Returns:Tuple containing the minimum and maximum order to evaluate.
Return type:tuple
HField(x, y, z)[source]¶

Value of the electric Field (First Order) ref[2]:Eq:6 \(H = H_0 \exp{ig( i k (z-z_0) ig) (p_x \vec{e_x}, p_y \vec{e_y})}\).

Hr(r, theta, phi)[source]¶

Value of the magnetic Field (First Order) ref[2]:Eq:10 \(H_r = E_0 \Phi_0 \Big[ \sin (\theta) \cos (\phi) - \frac{2Q}{kw_0^2} \cos (\theta) \big( r \sin (\theta) \cos (\phi) -y_0 \big) \Big] \exp^{ik (r \cos (\theta) -z_0 )}\).

Phi0(x, y, z)[source]¶

Method returns:

\(\Phi_0 = -i Q \exp \Big[ i Q \frac{(x-x_0)^2 + (y-y_0)^2}{w_0^2} \Big]\)

Phi0_Spherical(r, phi, theta)[source]¶

Method returns:

\(\Phi_0 = -i Q \exp \Big[ \frac{i Q}{w_0^2} \Big( (r \sin (\theta) \cos (\phi) - x_0^2 ) + (r \sin (\theta) \sin (\phi) - y_0^2 ) \Big) \Big]\)

Scatterer¶

Sphere¶

class PyMieSim.Scatterer.Sphere(Diameter: float, Source: PyMieSim.BaseClasses.BaseSource, Index: float, nMedium: float = 1.0, MuSphere: float = 1.0, MuMedium: float = 1.0)[source]¶

Bases: PyMieSim.BaseClasses.BaseScatterer, PyMieSim.BaseClasses.EfficienciesProperties

Short summary.

Parameters:
  • Diameter (float) – Diameter of the single scatterer in unit of meter.
  • Source (BaseSource) – Light source object containing info on polarization and wavelength.
  • Index (float) – Refractive index of scatterer
Area¶

Mathematical 2D area of the scatterer [\(\pi r^2\)].

Type:float
SizeParam¶

Size parameter of the scatterer [\(k r\)].

Type:float
EnergyFlow(Mesh)¶

Method return energy flow defined as:

\(W_a = \sigma_{sca} * I_{inc}\)

Where \(\sigma_{sca}\) is the scattering cross section.

More info on wikipedia link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_section_(physics)#Cross_section_and_Mie_theory

Parameters:Mesh (FibonacciMesh) – Number of voxel in the 4 pi space to compute energy flow.
Returns:Energy flow [\(W\)]
Return type:float
FarField(Num: int = 200)¶

Method Compute scattering Far Field.

Fields = \(\Big\{ E_{||}(\phi,\theta)^2, E_{\perp}(\phi,\theta)^2 \Big\}\).

The Fields are up to a constant phase value: \(\exp{(-i k r )}\)

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point to spatially (\(\phi , \theta\)) evaluate the Fields [Num, Num].
Returns:Dictionnay sub-class with all pertient information as keys.
Return type:ScalarField
GetEfficiencies()¶

Methode compute all Efficiences (\(Q_{sca}, Q_{ext}, Q_{abs}\)) for the scatterer.

PoyntingVector(Mesh)¶

Method return the Poynting vector norm defined as:

\(\vec{S} = \epsilon c^2 \vec{E} \times \vec{B}\)

Parameters:Mesh (FibonacciMesh) – Number of voxel in the 4 pi space to compute energy flow.
Returns:Poynting field [\(W/m^2\)]
Return type:np.array
Qabs¶

\(Q_{abs}=Q_{ext}-Q_{sca}\)

Type:Absorption efficiency
Qext¶

\(Q_{ext}=\frac{2}{x^2}\sum_{n=1}^{n_{max}}(2n+1) / \text{real} \{ a_n+b_n \}\)

Type:Extinction efficiency
Qsca¶

\(Q_{sca}=\frac{2}{x^2}\sum_{n=1}^{n_{max}}(2n+1)(|a_n|^2+|b_n|^2)\)

Type:Scattering efficiency
S1S2(Num=200)¶

Method compute \(S_1(\phi)\) and \(S_2(\phi)\). For spherical Scatterer such as here S1 and S2 are computed as follow:

\(S_1=\sum\limits_{n=1}^{n_{max}} \frac{2n+1}{n(n+1)}(a_n \pi_n+b_n \tau_n)\)

\(S_2=\sum\limits_{n=1}^{n_{max}}\frac{2n+1}{n(n+1)}(a_n \tau_n+b_n \pi_n)\)

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point (\(\phi\)) to evaluate \(S_1\) and \(S_2\).
Returns:Description of returned object.
Return type:S1S2
SPF(Num=100)¶

Scattering phase function.

SPF = \(E_{\parallel}(\phi,\theta)^2 + E_{\perp}(\phi,\theta)^2\)

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point to spatially (\(\theta , \phi\)) evaluate the SPF [Num, Num].
Returns:Dictionnay subclass with all pertinent information as keys.
Return type:SPF in PyMieSim
an(MaxOrder=5)[source]¶

Compute \(a_n\) coefficient as defined in Eq:III.88 of B&B:

\(a_n = \frac{ \mu_{sp} \Psi_n(\alpha) \Psi_n^\prime(\beta) - \mu M \Psi_n^\prime(\alpha) \Psi_n(\beta)} {\mu_{sp} \xi_n(\alpha) \Psi_n^\prime(\beta)- \mu M \xi_n^\prime (\alpha) \Psi_n(\beta)}\)

With \(M = \frac{k_{sp}}{k}\) (Eq:I.103)

bn(MaxOrder=5)[source]¶

Compute \(b_n\) coefficient as defined in Eq:III.89 of B&B:

\(b_n = \frac{ \mu M \Psi_n(\alpha) \Psi_n^\prime(\beta) - \mu_{sp} \Psi_n^\prime(\alpha) \Psi_n(\beta)} {\mu M \xi_n(\alpha) \Psi_n^\prime(\beta)- \mu_{sp} \xi_n^\prime (\alpha) \Psi_n(\beta)}\)

With \(M = \frac{k_{sp}}{k}\) (Eq:I.103)

cn(MaxOrder=5)[source]¶

Compute \(c_n\) coefficient as defined in Eq:III.90 of B&B:

\(c_n = \frac{ \mu_{sp} M \big[ \xi_n(\alpha) \Psi_n^\prime(\alpha) - \xi_n^\prime(\alpha) \Psi_n(\alpha) \big]} {\mu_{sp} \xi_n(\alpha) \Psi_n^\prime(\beta)- \mu M \xi_n^\prime (\alpha) \Psi_n(\beta)}\)

With \(M = \frac{k_{sp}}{k}\) (Eq:I.103)

dn(MaxOrder=5)[source]¶

Compute \(d_n\) coefficient as defined in Eq:III.91 of B&B:

\(d_n = \frac{ \mu M^2 \big[ \xi_n(\alpha) \Psi_n^\prime(\alpha) - \xi_n^\prime(\alpha) \Psi_n(\alpha) \big]} {\mu M \xi_n(\alpha) \Psi_n^\prime(\beta)- \mu_{sp} M \xi_n^\prime (\alpha) \Psi_n(\beta)}\)

With \(M = \frac{k_{sp}}{k}\) (Eq:I.103)

sFarField(Phi, Theta)¶

Method Compute scattering Far Field for structured coordinate.

Fields = \(E_{||}(\phi,\theta)^2, E_{\perp}(\phi,\theta)^2\)

The Fields are up to a constant phase value.

\(\exp{ig(-i k r ig)}\)

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point to spatially (\(\phi , \theta\)) evaluate the Fields [Num, Num].
uFarField(Phi, Theta)¶

Method Compute scattering Far Field for unstructured coordinate.

Fields = \(E_{||}(\phi,\theta)^2, E_{\perp}(\phi,\theta)^2\)

The Fields are up to a constant phase value.

\(\exp{ig(-i k r ig)}\)

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point to spatially (\(\phi , \theta\)) evaluate the Fields [Num, Num].

Cylinder¶

class PyMieSim.Scatterer.Cylinder(Diameter: float, Source: PyMieSim.BaseClasses.BaseSource, Index: float, IndexMedium: float = 1.0, MuSphere: float = 1.0, MuMedium: float = 1.0)[source]¶

More info on wikipedia link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_section_(physics)#Cross_section_and_Mie_theory

FarField(Num: int = 200)¶

The Fields are up to a constant phase value: \(\exp{(-i k r )}\)

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point to spatially (\(\phi , \theta\)) evaluate the Fields [Num, Num].
Returns:Dictionnay sub-class with all pertient information as keys.
Return type:ScalarField
GetEfficiencies()¶

Methode compute all Efficiences (\(Q_{sca}, Q_{ext}, Q_{abs}\)) for the scatterer.

PoyntingVector(Mesh)¶

Method return the Poynting vector norm defined as:

\(\vec{S} = \epsilon c^2 \vec{E} \times \vec{B}\)

Parameters:Mesh (FibonacciMesh) – Number of voxel in the 4 pi space to compute energy flow.
Returns:Poynting field [\(W/m^2\)]
Return type:np.array
Qabs¶

\(Q_{abs}=Q_{ext}-Q_{sca}\)

Type:Absorption efficiency
Qext¶

\(Q_{ext}=\frac{2}{x^2}\sum_{n=1}^{n_{max}}(2n+1) / \text{real} \{ a_n+b_n \}\)

Type:Extinction efficiency
Qsca¶

\(Q_{sca}=\frac{2}{x^2}\sum_{n=1}^{n_{max}}(2n+1)(|a_n|^2+|b_n|^2)\)

Type:Scattering efficiency
S1S2(Num=200)¶

Method compute \(S_1(\phi)\) and \(S_2(\phi)\). For spherical Scatterer such as here S1 and S2 are computed as follow:

\(S_1=\sum\limits_{n=1}^{n_{max}} \frac{2n+1}{n(n+1)}(a_n \pi_n+b_n \tau_n)\)

\(S_2=\sum\limits_{n=1}^{n_{max}}\frac{2n+1}{n(n+1)}(a_n \tau_n+b_n \pi_n)\)

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point (\(\phi\)) to evaluate \(S_1\) and \(S_2\).
Returns:Description of returned object.
Return type:S1S2
SPF(Num=100)¶

Scattering phase function.

SPF = \(E_{\parallel}(\phi,\theta)^2 + E_{\perp}(\phi,\theta)^2\)

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point to spatially (\(\theta , \phi\)) evaluate the SPF [Num, Num].
Returns:Dictionnay subclass with all pertinent information as keys.
Return type:SPF in PyMieSim
an(MaxOrder=5)[source]¶

Compute \(a_n\) coefficient as defined ref[5]:

\(a_n = \frac{ m_t J_n(m_t x) J_n^\prime (m x) - m J_n^\prime (m_t x) J_n(m x) } { m_t J_n(m_t x) H_n^\prime (m x) - m J_n^\prime (m_t x) H_n(m x) }\)

With \(m\) being the refractive index of the medium and
\(m_t\) being the refractive index of the index.
bn(MaxOrder=5)[source]¶

Compute \(b_n\) coefficient as defined in ref[5]:

\(b_n = \frac{ m J_n(m_t x) J_n^\prime (m x) - m_t J_n^\prime (m_t x) J_n(m x) } { m J_n(m_t x) H_n^\prime (m x) - m_t J_n^\prime (m_t x) H_n(m x) }\)

With \(m\) being the refractive index of the medium and
\(m_t\) being the refractive index of the index.
sFarField(Phi, Theta)¶

Method Compute scattering Far Field for structured coordinate.

Fields = \(E_{||}(\phi,\theta)^2, E_{\perp}(\phi,\theta)^2\)

The Fields are up to a constant phase value.

\(\exp{ig(-i k r ig)}\)

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point to spatially (\(\phi , \theta\)) evaluate the Fields [Num, Num].
uFarField(Phi, Theta)¶

Method Compute scattering Far Field for unstructured coordinate.

Fields = \(E_{||}(\phi,\theta)^2, E_{\perp}(\phi,\theta)^2\)

The Fields are up to a constant phase value.

\(\exp{ig(-i k r ig)}\)

Parameters:Num (int) – Number of point to spatially (\(\phi , \theta\)) evaluate the Fields [Num, Num].

WMSample¶

class PyMieSim.Scatterer.WMSample(g: float, lc: float, D: float, Nc: float, Source: PyMieSim.BaseClasses.BaseSource)[source]¶

Bases: object

Sample represented by the Whittle-Matern RI correlation function and using the first Born approximation .

Parameters:
  • g (float) – Description of parameter g.
  • lc (float) – Correlation lenght of RI of the sample
  • D (float) – Form factor of the sample
  • Nc (float) – Scalling factor of the sample.
  • Source (Source) – Light source object containing info on polarization and wavelength.

Detector¶

Photodiode¶

class PyMieSim.Detector.Photodiode(NA: float, Sampling: int = 400, GammaOffset: float = 0, PhiOffset: float = 0, Filter: float = None, CouplingMode: str = 'Centered')[source]¶

Bases: PyMieSim.BaseClasses.BaseDetector, PyMieSim.BaseClasses.MeshProperty

Detector type class representing a photodiode, light coupling is thus independant of the phase of the latter.

Parameters:
  • NA (float) – Numerical aperture of imaging system.
  • Sampling (int) – Number of sampling points for the mode (inside NA).
  • GammaOffset (float) – Angle offset of detector in the direction perpendicular to polarization.
  • PhiOffset (float) – Angle offset of detector in the direction parallel to polarization.
  • Filter (float) – Angle of polarization filter in front of detector. Default is “None”
  • CouplingMode (str) – Methode for computing mode coupling. Either Centered or Mean.
Coupling(Scatterer)¶

Return coupling power which is detected.

Parameters:Scatterer (Scatterer) – Scatterer instance (sphere, cylinder, …).
Returns:Value of the coupling power [\(W\)].
Return type:float
Footprint(Scatterer, Num=200)¶

Return the footprint of the scattererd light coupling with the detector as computed as:

\(\big| \mathscr{F}^{-1} \big\{ \tilde{ \psi } (\xi, \nu), \tilde{ \phi}_{l,m}(\xi, \nu) \big\}(\delta_x, \delta_y) \big|^2\).

where \(\Phi_{det}\) is the capturing field of the detector and \(\Psi_{scat}\) is the scattered field.

Parameters:Scatterer (Scatterer.) – Scatterer instance (sphere, cylinder, …).
Returns:Dictionnary subclass with all pertienent information.
Return type:Footprint.
Plot()¶

Method that plot the real part of the scattered field (\(E_{\theta}\) and \(E_{\phi}\)).

SphericalMesh(Sampling, MaxAngle, PhiOffset=0, GammaOffset=0, Structured=True)¶

Method that return an angular mesh (\(\theta\), \(\phi\)) which is either structured or not. If not the pattern follow a Fibonacci mesh.

StructuredFarField(Num=100, SFactor=None)[source]¶

Compute the FarField in a structured Mesh.

Parameters:
  • Num (int) – Dimension of the structured mesh [Num, Num].
  • SFactor (float) – Unused parameter added to match LPmode class.
Returns:

Structured FarField value.

LPmode¶

class PyMieSim.Detector.LPmode(Mode: tuple, NA: float, Sampling: int = 401, InterpSampling: int = 101, GammaOffset: float = 0, PhiOffset: float = 0, Filter: float = None, CouplingMode: str = 'Centered')[source]¶

Bases: PyMieSim.BaseClasses.BaseDetector, PyMieSim.BaseClasses.MeshProperty

Detector type class representing a fiber LP mode, light coupling is thus dependant of the phase of the latter.

Parameters:
  • Mode (tuple) – LP mode index l, m.
  • NA (float) – Numerical aperture of imaging system.
  • Sampling (int) – Number of sampling points for the mode (inside NA).
  • InterpSampling (int) – Number of sampling point for interpolation of FarField mode.
  • GammaOffset (float) – Angle offset of detector in the direction perpendicular to polarization.
  • PhiOffset (float) – Angle offset of detector in the direction parallel to polarization.
  • Filter (float) – Angle of polarization filter in front of detector. Default is “None”
  • CouplingMode (str) – Methode for computing mode coupling. Either [Centered or Mean].
Coupling(Scatterer)¶

Return coupling power which is detected.

Parameters:Scatterer (Scatterer) – Scatterer instance (sphere, cylinder, …).
Returns:Value of the coupling power [\(W\)].
Return type:float
FarField(Num, Interpolate)[source]¶

Compute the FarField in a structured Mesh and interpolate the Mesh.

Parameters:Num (int) – Dimension of the structured mesh [Num, Num].
Returns:Structured FarField value.
Return type:FraunhoferDiffraction
Footprint(Scatterer, Num=200)¶

\(\big| \mathscr{F}^{-1} \big\{ \tilde{ \psi } (\xi, \nu), \tilde{ \phi}_{l,m}(\xi, \nu) \big\}(\delta_x, \delta_y) \big|^2\).

where \(\Phi_{det}\) is the capturing field of the detector and \(\Psi_{scat}\) is the scattered field.

Parameters:Scatterer (Scatterer.) – Scatterer instance (sphere, cylinder, …).
Returns:Dictionnary subclass with all pertienent information.
Return type:Footprint.
